summary: Over 2020-2024, Mercedes accumulated 82 FIA infringement decisions. The yearly distribution shows a varying trend, with 11 incidents in 2020, 16 in 2021, 15 in 2022, 23 in 2023, and 17 in 2024. The leading infraction categories across these years include track limits breaches, technical breaches, and procedural mistakes, with track limits breaches being the most frequent in 2020 and 2023, and technical breaches leading in 2021 and 2024. Penalty-wise, time penalties were the most common, ranging from 31.25% in 2021 to 43.5% in 2023, followed by fines, reprimands, and other penalties. Driver Lewis Hamilton was involved in the majority of incidents, with 91% in 2020, 50% in 2021, 53.3% in 2022, 56.5% in 2023, and 41.2% in 2024, while Driver George Russell accounted for the remaining incidents. The peak year for infringements was 2023 with 23 incidents, and the yearly average is approximately 16.4 incidents. Session analysis reveals that most incidents occurred during races, with 47.1% in 2024, 52.2% in 2023, and 40% in 2022, followed by qualifying and practice sessions. The overall trend from 2020 to 2024 shows an increase in track limits breaches and technical breaches, highlighting the need for Mercedes to improve their adherence to FIA regulations and minimize future infringements.
